audio_caption: The audio clip begins with an upbeat, rhythmic instrumental piece featuring prominent percussion. Following this, a male speaker begins a tutorial, explaining the process of exporting and installing a mod into a 1.14 version of Minecraft. He emphasizes the need for Forge and the Java edition, and advises listeners to read the MCreator EULA, summarizing that while selling the mod isn't allowed, accepting donations is permissible under certain conditions.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing how to export a mod in a software, mentioning a specific icon that says "export the mod for distribution" and keyboard shortcuts such as Control+E. The speaker explains that the version of the software determines Minecraft compatibility, indicating a tutorial or explanation setting.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing the process of reading a EULA, agreeing, and exporting a mod. He continues to describe how to save the mod in a format that people can read, giving it a personal name that includes the Minecraft version and mod version. The speaker adds information about how a properly named file makes it easy for people to identify the mod's details. He instructs the listener to click save and mentions that it will save to a folder, adding that you can click the home icon to save it to the desktop if desired. He concludes the segment by stating that he has covered everything that needs to be done in this particular part of the process.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining how to install a mod. He sounds instructional, saying the mod is "right here" and specifying the need for Forge. He directs listeners to "Minecraftforge.net," instructing them to choose the appropriate version and download the recommended installer.  After completing installation he mentions the next step will be double-clicking on the installer.

The audio begins with a male speaker providing instructions, explaining that one needs to click "install server" when setting up a Minecraft server. He goes on to clarify the difference between a client and server version, stating that a client is for personal use, but players joining must install the client as well. A click sound punctuates the explanation as he advises installing the server version if running a server. The speaker then continues explaining to simply click "okay" and it will automatically install the Forge version for your client.

The clip begins with a single speaker explaining that once everything is set up, it'll only take a few seconds, depending on the computer's speed. Speaking in an informative and somewhat technical tone, the speaker then directs the listener to the Minecraft launcher, specifically to the "installations" section where a Forge version should be present. The speaker mentions that one is currently unnamed, but contains "1.14 Forge" and the Forge version number. The speaker transitions to saying that they'll make a new profile using this version.

The audio clip begins with a speaker, likely male based on tone, instructing someone: "So to do that, we're going to click on the little plus icon up at the top of the list." His tone is instructional and clear. Then he continues with "and there."

The audio clip begins with someone speaking, explaining that they're going to go to their ".minecraft" folder. The speech is informational and delivered in a neutral tone. Then, the speaker describes how to access the relevant folder by typing "%appdata%". A brief sound occurs during the speech but its type and contribution is unclear.

The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing creating a 'profiles' folder for Minecraft, suggesting it's good practice when using mods and different versions of the game. He describes the process of creating a new profile, including naming it in a specific format, followed by copying its path.

The clip starts with a male speaker detailing a technical process, mentioning specifics such as "Minecraft Forge" and "1.14.4" in a neutral and instructional tone. He then transitions to discussing options and versions for the process. There is a shift to describing how to play and generate files with the profile. The speaker continues, mentioning exporting a mod after completion. The discussion moves to configuring settings, including details like chunks, disabling music and auto-jump. There's a remark about setting controls, disabling bobbing and maximizing certain settings, concluding that "that's good". The segment closes with the speaker preparing to exit the game and drop the mod into the mods folder within the same profile.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, who appears to be giving a tutorial by describing technical steps. He mentions being in the same profile that was set up for a "forge," and then, there is a brief glitchy sound, reminiscent of a "bleep." The male speaker then continues with the description, noting that "your mods are in here and then you're just going to drop your mod into the mods folder." After this, the speaker mentions relauncing Minecraft, and states it will take a second to load up and check if the mods are working. Finally, he notes how to test if the mods are working by clicking on mods and seeing if the file is loaded and says if that is not the case, you might want to re-export and make sure the correct version for forge is installed. To conclude, he proposes clicking on a quick single-player world.

The audio clip begins with a person speaking in a casual tone, discussing selecting "creative" and confirming a mod is working. This leads into a general explanation, including "I have a new tab, so it's right here, that's perfect". Concluding with a thanks to the listener for watching. Transitioning to a short music section that could be classified as a backing track or incidental music, featuring a synthetic sound.
